comment:
It seems that whereever in Africa you look, the source of problems boils down to one thing: lack of private property rights.
 
Let me make the case: if the Africans had clear private titles to land the live on, they could legally defend them and even use force. They want the land to last from father to son.
 
When the land is public and/or on rent, it is easily corrupted and overused. Public officals take bribes and look past illegalities. The cure: better private property rights for Africans.

comment: Devolved government may help this situation, meaning every region should have their own elected governor or elected DCE’s so that those people are directly accountable to their immediate people. Winner takes all government is dangerous because if 8 years they get they need to accumulate enough to last them the next 8 years but if they know that opposition is also going to give them some income all politicians, chief executives, DCE’s and the rest may behave well. Here in UK this kind of problem will be under council and if it gets worse that’s when central government comes in. The council collects local taxes and sends you periodic breakdown of what your taxes are used for that how much local police gets and bin collectors etc. The point is the council is voted by only local residents. If I have problems I don’t go to the prime minister at least until I know the council cannot handle my issues. Devolution of government releases the burden on central government Nigerians have this type of system too. Of course it’s has its drawbacks.

comment: It's very clear that Ghana's Gift Policy under the National Anti Corruption Action Plan (NACAP) makes it compulsory for public office holders and public servants to hand over gifts received to their heads of institutions.  Heads of institutions will take the final decision on the disposal of the gift.  Public servants are required to sign and make a gift statement every quarter under the Ghana Gift Policy.  Copies of the gift statement are to be signed and handed over to institution heads who will forward them to  the CHRAJ.  All public servants must declare whether they accept or decline a gift that is offered.

comment: Bro, there is something called  code of conduct. Code of Conduct highlights, reasonable behavior and conduct in relation to giving what we call gifts & favors, kickback, confidential information, conflict of interest, control and use of assets and information, inside trading, political contribution and etc. The idea of code of conduct is to ascertain that no employee, member of an organization or government doesn't compromise themselves in any interaction, communication or dealings at any point in time of their association to an entity during or after their their association with that institution. I think corporations in Ghana have literally thrown out the above practice and perhaps many are aware yet don't heed to the statues and remifications of the same. So those who are aware and heed to such policies know that they cannot accept any amount of money in the name of tip/thank you, gift or favor from any one during, before or after office hours in the face of dealings that has to do with an organization that the officer, personnel or person is employed by. It's quite a simple policy but our culture disregards it. The ramifications is really unsustainable corporations. There are no jobs because certain individuals are making their own corner deals which shutters and negates their employer from thousands and in some cases millions of income.

comment: Well I agree with you to some point, but I believe the issue here is not necessarily an official demanding money before doing something for them. In most institutions, it is part of their policy that, no staff should accept a gift from other party because it can lead to the staff doing something in favor of that party.  I have notice in Ghana especially in the banking sector that, taking gifts has become something enjoyable and that it has become a normal way of life which in a way is not right. Consider ethics and ask yourself, can the gift that I'm taking have an influence on the decision I will make in the future with the party that gave me the gift?

comment: I must congratulate you on how you have added another dimension to your arsenal but analyzing topical issues albeit with your dose of humour and comedy. You also never fail to pick on your man Capito lol. Good analyzes but think you went off a bit around the gift issue. Your opinion was well and seem very frank. However, on the bribery issue you make a mistake which most Gh people make because of the cultural orientation that leads to bribery (the culture of gift giving/demands unnecessarily as a show of appreciation) and the other underdeveloped structures in the country. The structures and systems are bad and slow so they frustrate people and so people show gratitude when somehow helps out albeit that they are doing their work. This is unethical and borders on bribery. If you live in Europe and you apply for a job no matter the number of applicants etc no appreciation gift is demanded or accepted. Till we LEARN that as Gh people, even if the person volunteers the amount without our asking etc,  we will NEVER have a handle on corruption BAM!!!!! We should learn the ethics of employment conditions etc these are not waiters. You think Nana Addo should accept money from foreign millionaires etc because they appreciate his style of governance?

comment: Sometimes you try really hard to appear neutral and that masks the truth. Tell me where else in the developed world a government or civic official accepts cash gifts to perform their role or in this case "expedite processes"? The police, government officials, and crooks with access to government official (this should tell you everything about the government official who stepped down after he got caught) should not accept cash "gifts" to do their jobs? It is never a gift accepting money that will influence decisions to bypass bureaucracies. In your video you keep saying you yourself will take monies offered because of a meager salary but this is (speaks volumes of something called integrity and the lack thereof) the root of bribery when even through expose' you still condoning and rationalizing corruption. I know you do satiric sketches but u need to realise you have a platform and an opportunity to change the narrative. People in government sectors, positions of power with ability to influence decisions should really reconsider taking monies in form of gifts because its flat out wrong and should be condemned. If people wana accept tips then they should take bar tending or waiter jobs because thats an institution based on money for service.

comment: I do like your videos and how you use comedy sometimes to bring light to current issues. On this video, some of your explanations seems to be a bit off. Which is why it is causing some confusion among your followers as to whether taking money as gift was bribery or not. I suppose you should have defined what bribery is or what constitutes bribery in a government setting first before following up with you opinions/explanations on the subject. According to wex law dictionary this is what Bribery means.."Bribery refers to the offering, giving, soliciting, or receiving of any item of value as a means of influencing the actions of an individual holding a public or legal duty. ... Solicitation of a bribe also constitutes a crime and is completed regardless of whether the solicitation results in the receipt of a valuable gift. In other words Magraheb, some of your explanations are not right and I think you owe it to your faithful viewers to come back with a right explanations on this subject. That been said I believe you have a great platform and your show is one of a kind. God bless our homeland Ghana.

comment: #STOP-THE-GALAMSEY-NOW. Are we worthy of nature’s gift of minerals? If we need the Gold, why not the government mining it and selling it to these Chinese and the World at large? We know the harm Surface Mining does to the forest, our water bodies and the ecology with the participation of weak private companies whose sole aim is prospecting for gold. These weak companies careless when they destroy the rivers by using it for washing the gold. In fact, almost invariably, they divert the river to concentrate it into their dugout ponds. The code of conduct for Surface Mining includes reclaiming the land by levelling the already mined area by backfiling it and replanting the tree to regrow the forest which could take another 10-15 years to achieve. This exercise is so strenuous that only  well-structured companies have the time and resources to accomplish. Just allowing people with African mentally to mine our forest is unhelpful and dangerous. We Africans don't care about the consequences of the devastation of the forest, rivers and the landscape and the consequences of the eminent errosion that will follow. If we cannot control the immediate harm Surface Mining brings, let's leave the gold in the soil and do our traditional farming on the land up until some sensible crop of Ghanaians come with a good plan to start mining the gold. Gold could be a gift and a curse in the same breath. Stop galamsey all over. Even when we will allow Surface mining, the distance between concessions should be not less than 10Km from each other and two concessions in every 30Km stretch. The rules should be stringent and tight to avoid negative impact on our environment. Such activity requires regular inspection by the government. Each Operation Site should be equipped with at least two water tankers. You see now, none of the sites we found escavators working there had Water Tankers, meaning, the rivers serving the communities nearby are used directly by the miners to wash their gold TOO BAD!!!!. In all things, put Ghana first, Mahama and Nana Addo, this is your call. I hate when a party wins power, they sacrifice our safety on the Altar of distributing our natural resources to party supporters and family. Look, if America, the UK, Germany, Russia, France, Japa, Korea moved along our lines, they would by now be extinct. Instead, they have grown from strength to strength. Anytime, I hear developed countries insulting Africans. Our Leaders are not there for the preservation of our people and the land. My Canadian Boss told me if he came to Africa to think and work  like Africans, he would also be poor like Africans. A word to the wise is enough. Ghana and Korea and Malaysia had indelendence about the same time, they dint have the resouces we have but look at the difference. I want to see selfless leaders who will come and improve our lot but not to sell off our resources to enrich himself and party faithfuls. Now, let's change leadership qualification for Ghana. At every party's congress, the presidential candidate should be assembled and be interviewed by a panel of Journalists and professionals organised by the EC and the best 3 candidates should go for election at the Congress. That way, the best candidate could emerge. No screening, no voting.

comment: Mr. President, please, as a matter of urgency, declare a state of Emergency on  all the mining areas. I know for a fact that all the approved mining companies are doing surface mining and only in Obuasi I saw an underground mining by Anglogold. I built communication links everywhere for Ashanti Goldfield, Amansie Resources, in Amansie off Bekwai, Teberebe in Tarkwa, Goldfield Ghana in Abosso in Daman, AGL in Bibiani, Ayanfuri,  Sansu and I think most of those sites were surface mining. For Amansie Resources, I saw them replanting the trees they destroyed. The had dug out Ponds for washing the gold. Also, if Escavators are found lined up along the road especially where there is no road construction activity going on. The Operation Teams should question their purposes for any parked Escavators being where they are parked. Such Escavators may have been removed hurriedly from the mine sites for fear of being burnt. This Operation should be equipped with night overhead patrol capability using helicopters to find the Galamsey miners by night. Our Lands and Rivers and Forests are under attack. Know that, we migrated from the Old Ghana Empire  to the present day Ghana due poor water sources, bad land and war. If we obliterate these mainstays, where will we go to settle in this era of defined territorial boundaries documented and recognized by the United Nations? Let’s be wise about the situation but not to read politics into it. The NDC should support this War against our Environment. No foolish Politics over here.

comment: Lol.. I understand the outburst of emotions but let's not talk about prayers because most people don't know what prayers are or what to expect when they pray, that's why it's not working. Prayer will not work if not backed by corresponding action. The root question we should be asking is why? Why are these people doing what they're doing? I once asked someone who had a galamsey site how much gold they expect to get from that site? According to the person, they were not even expecting to get up to a cup of gold after digging and destroying the land. So why are they doing it? They don't know what else to do,  for most people. Skill acquisition and creating systems of employment including an enabling environment for entrepreneurs is what we need. Let's focus on sustainable and meaningful development and not what had been sold to us as development. E.g. Instead of destroying that sane land for let's assume 1 cup of gold which we'll sell of and spend in max. a few years, we can plant and process foods which will be a sustainable industry for several years.

comment: I can comfortably outline why things have gotten to this point and how it is almost impossible to stop this menace....bros it's more than just people wanting to destroy lands and water bodies....the very basis of our minerals and mining laws are a scam itself... Right from when the white man drafted the first constitution till now...we have been living a delusion for decades and we hate the real truth be told. Like I have been saying ..Cocoa farming is a scam and until cocoa farmers see a change in their lives forget it neo-galamsey isn't stopping...many farmers now see value selling off some of their lands than working them like slaves.. sending the police and military taskforce is just creating a false avenue for them to enrich themselves....there are areas where miners re informed of operations before it's done... zero presence on site by the time task forces get on site...until the rural communities see a change in their local economies and poverty reduces forget it cuz no government can fight this without the cooperation of the galamsey communities themselves. We have ignored and relegated these communities for too long..An agricultural country whose middle class and elite look down on Agric , what do you expect? No substantial investments etc .. we had rather pursue engineering courses with a absolutely no job market here than expand Agric studies which has enough opportunities here all in the name of some freaking prestige..We seldom are pragmatic. Ssme colonial era stance... our educate populace are clueless and for our leaders only God knoweth. A common graduate lingering around the offices of cocoaboard earns more in a month than what some cocoa farmers with over 10acres of cocoa earn in a year yet these same white collar workers will clutch and hijack every opportunity in a cocoa scholarship scheme whilst wards of cocoa farmers are left at the mercy of less education..where is the cocoa board head office situated? In a non cocoa growing region. ....infact a gold nugget the size of a cocoa bean is worth more than several sacks of cocoa....who doesn't want money or we in the big cities think we re the only ones that deserve the good life and looting and scheming around the national cake? What we re seeing with galamsey is not just a menace but the reward for our fullness, indifference, non patriotism, greed, inequity, indecisions and ill orientation. comment: This is appalling Ghana, using Ghanaian soldiers to protect Chinese illegal miners. Ghana always made us believe that it needs money to build the country and they would go all over the world to borrow money at high interest rates and yet still they got Chinese people here to destroy our precious forests and ecology and looted all our wealth.  What is the sense in all these?. Somebody tells me. I know all these forest devastation by the Chinese started when NDC was in power.  I  also heard that the soldiers NANA AKUFO-ADDO sent to combat illegal miners has themselves turned to illegal mining. It was apparently in the recent election that who was illegal mining champion Mahama or Nana. While Nana and his magnificent NPP party were telling the voters to stop illegal mining. comment: We all heard the way the Staff Sgt who made the call talked, if you hear a soldier with a shake in his voice, you know he's not doing what's right. Env Minister says the company has exploration license, yet they're being guarded by military and there's Chinese presence. Shows how we have failed as a nation. Even the president knows about these operations, he just turns a blind eye. On "breaking day" (i.e. the day when the gold, concentrate is traded for cash) they send some very far, even to the owner of the land, and we all know whom this is. All our leaders are complacent. NDC did it and that's how Maj Mahama was killed, they were protecting a similar investment, NPP is doing it, the next one to come will do it. They just talk, it's empty noise. Have we ever wondered why Ghana is so expensive and there's free flow of dollars in the land? Such dubious enterprises are the cause. We have failed as a nation, even most of our friends who are making noise on social media, would even do worse, should they be given the opportunity. Have we ever heard Operation Vanguard, Galamstop, Env Ministry and all those state institutions involved in this fight against illegal mining declaring what has been seized during the raids, but for the usual excavators? What happened to the bullion, the gold concentrate, the dollars, pounds, euro, yuan, cedis, the mercury and all the likes?? Well that's the big money...so those figures, we shall never know. Those in charge have become millionaires in a matter of days, cus they under declared, or never declared what was seized. As for the Tundras and Tacomas they have been parked in people's garages in Accra. These should have been sold, and together with the hard cash, used to reclaim the land and restore the forest. Send crack soldiers down there, let miners together with the Chinese use the excavators to reclaim the land, back fill and spend time replanting. We can only weep for our nation, things would not change, don't forget the next group of greedy bastards are being bred and undergoing training as PA to many of our big men
